body: @rayjan0114 thanks for the example! Did you see improvements after implementing this type of image augmentation? If so and you think it might help others you might consider submitting this as a PR.

@glenn-jocher 
Sure, I can submit that.
I do have some improvement in my own data, but I don't have a beautiful test plot for the comparison, because it takes too long to test mAP and we are chasing the competition deadline. 
We closed the testing and tested the backup.pt on the other computer to know where we are.

When we closed the augmentation and only opened augment_hsv and cutout, we did have some mAP improvement on our self-driving data like the paper claims, but the cause and effect require further experiments.

@rayjan0114 I've added cutouts now inspired by your work in commit https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/commit/9a18166382d07985b6c2b671fdb4b4d5bfac1ef5.

This additionally removes heavily obscured labels (i.e. >80% obscured by the cutout), and randomly sizes the cutout in height and width.
@rayjan0114 edit, I increased the threshold for label removal to >90% obscured. This is inline with the rest of the augmentation strategy.

Nice job man!

Being busy these days on other new projects.

I am glad my feedback can help!

thanks for sharing again

Here's a training batch with cutouts for reference. In one of the images you can see there's one skateboarder (I think) almost completely obscured, but since he's not >90% obscured the box remains. Maybe I should lower that to 80% not sure.

I have a feeling this implementation is benefiting large objects more than small objects, as most small objects may simply be 100% obscured and removed from the labels for that batch, which is not really the intention. More smaller cutouts may help this, perhaps in 3 levels, large, medium and small, with say 1, 4, and 16 cutouts in them?

![train_batch0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26833433/65677590-2f7a6000-e052-11e9-8556-ad4949936a79.jpg)

@rayjan0114 I'm testing a multiscale cutout approach. 1 cutout up to 50% image size, 4 up to 25%, and 16 up to 12.5%. This is what it looks like. I'll post the results of a comparison study here for reference.

![train_batch0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26833433/66253917-6f86c480-e76f-11e9-9dcb-174a18c47ee8.jpg)

Nice try!
Thanks for sharing

When one thing really gets covered overall, does it mean you should take out the label so that the machine would not be forced to see something it can't see? 
The same reason as you said it might be for the large object in original intention.

Does this really boost some performance in your experiment?

What an amazing approach!
thanks for sharing
yeah, cutout was mean to mimick something is blocking the sight of a self-driving car

@rayjan0114 ya absolutely I'm surprised cutouts hurt our mAP. Before when it helped we were using Adam with different hyperparameters, now with SGD and the default hyps it actually hurts mAP a bit. Maybe the largest squares are too large (up to 0.5 width/height).
